The ongoing conflict in Gaza has resulted in extensive civilian harm, with explosive weapons causing significant damage in densely populated areas and leading to forced displacement orders. This situation necessitates urgent action to protect civilians from escalating violence and ensure the safe delivery of humanitarian aid[1]. Israeli airstrikes have recently targeted at least six UN-run schools sheltering displaced Palestinians, raising concerns about the repeated attacks on shelters for Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) in the Strip[11][14]. In the past 72 hours alone, these strikes have resulted in tens of fatalities, including children and women[14][17].

Specific incidents include Israeli airstrikes on a mosque and the Ibn Rushd School in Al-Zawaida, both sheltering displaced civilians in central Gaza, which killed at least 24 Palestinians, including children, and injured 93 others[12][13]. The displaced Palestinian population faces the grim reality of being ordered from one area to another, only to be bombed in the schools and tents where they seek refuge[15]. The dire conditions in Gaza are exacerbated by poor water, sanitation, and hygiene, along with overcrowding in shelters, which are primary drivers of disease outbreaks[26]. The lack of clean water and hygiene products has led to outbreaks of diarrhea and skin diseases[21], while the breakdown of sanitation infrastructure has resulted in a proliferation of disease vectors[22]. The collapse of waste management systems, including hazardous medical waste, contributes to contamination[25], and the inability to maintain hygiene severely impacts health, increasing the risk of epidemics[27][25].

Israeli airstrikes have severely impacted safety and living conditions in Gaza, with over 370,000 housing units damaged and 79,000 homes completely destroyed[32]. Approximately 68% of cropland and roads have also been severely damaged, leading to overcrowding and appalling sanitary conditions[32][37]. Food scarcity and the lack of clean water and hygiene products continue to cause outbreaks of diarrhea and skin diseases[31]. As of September 2024, only 17 of 36 hospitals remain partially functional, suffering from a lack of fuel, medical supplies, and clean water due to constant Israeli attacks[32].

The conflict has also severely impacted maternity care in Gaza, contributing to a rise in miscarriages, obstetric complications, low birth weight, and premature births, primarily due to stress, malnutrition, and a near-total lack of maternity care[41]. Ala'a, a pregnant woman, was forced to leave her home and live in a tent at seven months pregnant. She delivered her baby, Mohammad, in a field hospital in Khan Younis, which featured a specialized maternity unit supported by UK-Med and the UN agency for sexual and reproductive health, UNFPA[50][47]. Despite the ongoing war and lack of resources, Ala'a and her newborn recovered well, expressing gratitude to the hospital staff[47][50]. However, continuous support for health services is impossible without a ceasefire, full access, and sustained funding[48].

The conflict has profoundly impacted individuals like Taleen Al-Hinnawi and Nada Al-Gharib. Taleen lost her father and is adjusting to life in the Al-Baraka orphanage camp, where she finds a sense of community despite the shock and sadness[51]. Nada lost her father and brother and was injured in a strike on their tent in Khan Younis. Despite the hardships, she remains resilient, stating, "We love our lives. Even though it's hard and the loss of our loved ones is hard for us, we try to live for them"[58].

The Israeli military's Operation Iron Swords included a complete blockade of the Gaza Strip, resulting in a death toll exceeding 41,800 since October 7, according to the enclave's health ministry[91]. Thousands are reported missing under the rubble of destroyed buildings[96]. Heavy Israeli strikes have been reported across northern Gaza, with first responders unable to reach several hit homes and buildings due to bombardment[96]. The Israeli army has issued evacuation orders, leading people to leave their homes without knowing where to go or having means of transportation[91]. Strikes have targeted shelters, including a mosque and a school, killing people who were sheltering there[91]. Children are suffering, and hunger is spreading due to almost no basic supplies being available[98].

The conflict has raised deep concerns about mental health in Gaza, with over 485,000 people diagnosed with mental disorders before the war[102]. Humanitarian organizations are addressing these issues by running psychosocial support sessions for over 94,000 children and offering mental health services[107][102]. The World Health Organization (WHO) calls for a de-escalation of the conflict, advocating for healthcare to be protected, access routes to be secured, and supplies to be delivered. WHO also calls for a ceasefire, a political solution, and peace, with Tedros stating that "The best medicine is peace"[111].

Israeli military operations in Gaza have resulted in significant impacts on the civilian population, including fatalities, injuries, and displacement. More than 41,500 people have been killed, with children killed en masse[131][136]. There have also been 765 deaths resulting from at least 516 attacks on healthcare in Gaza since October 2023[131]. Over 96,000 people have been wounded, and at least 12,000 people are in desperate need of medical evacuation[135]. The civilian population has been repeatedly displaced and forced into smaller and smaller areas under bombardments, living in overcrowded and inhumane conditions[133][140].

Military operations in the West Bank have caused significant damage to civilian infrastructure, including the forced demolition of over 2,000 Palestinian homes and massive damage to public infrastructure, such as roads[151]. These operations contribute to extreme mental distress and increased mental health concerns among the West Bank population[152].

Women in Gaza face a double burden, becoming heads of their households amidst destruction and navigating survival and care[161]. Pregnant and breastfeeding mothers have experienced immense difficulties due to the collapse in healthcare services[161]. Children in Gaza are experiencing profound trauma, grappling with anxiety and severe physical injuries, with many having lost limbs[164][166]. They have missed an entire year of education, and schools sheltering displaced families have been repeatedly shelled[163]. Over five times more children were killed in Gaza in the last year than between 2005 and 2022 combined[169]. Approximately 17,000 children are unaccompanied or separated, and 625,000 children have been out of school for a whole year[163].

Humanitarian organizations are addressing these challenges in several ways. Oxfam partner Juzoor is supporting hundreds of thousands of people in over 90 shelters and health points across Gaza[161]. UNICEF has vaccinated thousands of children for polio in the area[161]. Oxfam is calling for an immediate, permanent ceasefire, the release of all hostages and unlawfully detained Palestinians, and an end to all lethal arms sales to Israel[166]. They also demand full humanitarian access to Gaza and urge the international community to enforce accountability by addressing the illegal Israeli occupation, removing settlements in the occupied West Bank, and providing reparations to affected Palestinian communities[166].

Signatory organizations consider the ongoing dehumanization of Lebanese civilians distressing, urging governments to impose sanctions, such as an arms embargo on Israel, for its gross violations of international law[171]. At least 885 healthcare workers have been killed, and women have had caesarians and children amputations without anesthetics[172].

The ongoing conflict in Gaza has resulted in extensive civilian harm, with explosive weapons in densely populated areas causing significant casualties and forced displacement. Urgent action is necessary to protect civilians from escalating violence and ensure the safe delivery of humanitarian aid [1]. The situation is exacerbated by logistical challenges faced by organizations like the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), which struggles to deliver agricultural aid due to restrictions at crossings and the collapse of law and order [11]. FAO is prepared to provide more support to Gazan farmers and herders once access and security conditions improve [19].

The forced movement of populations has disrupted the operations of aid partners, leading the World Food Programme (WFP) to halt food basket distributions in Gaza due to critically restricted flows of essential goods [21]. Israeli airstrikes have targeted UN-run schools sheltering displaced Palestinians, causing fatalities and injuries, including among children and women [31][34][37]. In one instance, airstrikes on a mosque and the Ibn Rushd School in Al-Zawaida killed at least 24 Palestinians and injured 93 others [32][33]. These attacks have forced families to move from one area to another, only to be bombed in the shelters where they seek refuge [35].

The humanitarian crisis is compounded by poor water, sanitation, and hygiene conditions, which are primary drivers of disease in Gaza [46]. The lack of clean water and hygiene products has led to outbreaks of diarrhea and skin diseases [41], while the breakdown of sanitation infrastructure has increased disease vectors [42]. The collapse of waste management systems, including hazardous medical waste, further contaminates the environment [45]. Overcrowding in shelters and the inability to maintain hygiene severely impact health, with the risk of epidemics rising [47][45].

Israeli airstrikes have devastated Gaza's infrastructure, damaging over 370,000 housing units and destroying 79,000 homes [52]. Approximately 68% of cropland and roads have been severely damaged, leading to overcrowding and poor sanitary conditions [57]. Food scarcity and the lack of clean water exacerbate health issues, with only 17 of 36 hospitals remaining partially functional due to a lack of fuel, medical supplies, and clean water [52].

The conflict has severely impacted maternity care, contributing to increased miscarriages, obstetric complications, and premature births due to stress, malnutrition, and inadequate healthcare [61]. Ala'a, a pregnant woman, was forced to deliver her baby in a field hospital in Khan Younis after experiencing early labor and multiple evacuations [70][61]. Despite the challenges, Ala'a and her newborn recovered well, thanks to the dedicated health staff [67][70]. However, continuous support for health services is impossible without a ceasefire and sustained funding [68].

Individuals like Taleen Al-Hinnawi and Nada Al-Gharib have been profoundly affected by the conflict. Taleen lost her father and now lives in the Al-Baraka orphanage camp, where she struggles with shock and sadness [71]. Nada lost her father and brother and was injured in a strike on their tent in Khan Younis [72][73]. Despite the hardships, both individuals find a sense of community and resilience among those who share similar experiences [71][78].

The conflict has also led to significant damage to civilian infrastructure in the West Bank, including the demolition of over 2,000 Palestinian homes and damage to public infrastructure [201]. This has resulted in forced displacement and increased mental health concerns among the population [202]. Women in Gaza face additional burdens, becoming heads of households and navigating survival amidst destruction [211]. Children experience profound trauma, with many suffering from anxiety, severe injuries, and disrupted education [214][216].

Humanitarian organizations are addressing these challenges by providing support in shelters, health points, and through vaccination programs [211]. Oxfam and UNICEF are calling for a ceasefire, humanitarian access, and accountability for violations of international law [216]. The international community is urged to end arms sales that fuel the violence and to hold perpetrators accountable for serious violations [172][174].

The conflict has severely impacted essential services and resources in Gaza, with hundreds of thousands lacking access to food and clean water [247]. The destruction of agricultural land and infrastructure has limited food availability, while water contamination and damaged infrastructure exacerbate health risks [243][244]. The UN and humanitarian partners have developed a Winterization Plan to address critical needs, but interventions are hindered by restricted access and resource availability [245][249].

The World Health Organization (WHO) calls for a de-escalation of the conflict, protection of healthcare, and a ceasefire to ensure peace and access to essential services [151]. The international community's response to calls for a ceasefire has been mixed, with ongoing military support to Israel complicating efforts [179]. Despite these challenges, organizations continue to advocate for an immediate and lasting ceasefire and accountability for violations of international humanitarian law [173][174].

The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) faces significant logistical challenges in delivering agricultural aid to Gaza, primarily due to restrictions at crossings and the collapse of law and order, which severely constrain their efforts[1]. Despite these obstacles, FAO is prepared to provide more inputs to Gazan farmers and herders once conditions of access, security, and mobility are restored[9]. However, the current strategies to address these challenges remain unspecified.

In Gaza, the destruction of homes and infrastructure has profoundly affected the daily lives of residents. An Islamic Relief staff member reported that their own house is damaged and uninhabitable, and that their siblings and colleagues have also lost their homes[21]. The staff member further noted that their Islamic Relief office, along with children's schools, a mosque, a hospital, restaurants, and a church, have been destroyed, leading to a systematic dismantling of their lives[21]. The extent of the destruction is so severe that even if the conflict were to cease, returning to their homes would be impossible[21].

Civilian infrastructure, including schools, religious buildings, hospitals, and bakeries, has been decimated[22]. The healthcare system has been systematically dismantled, with most primary healthcare centers out of action[23][26]. Critical services such as oncology, MRI, specialized pediatric surgery, and endocrinology are no longer available[24]. The lack of electricity, except for generators that are costly to operate due to high fuel prices, has led to a significant drop in access to essential services like water, food, and education, creating a "real shock" for the population[28]. Additionally, there is a rise in infectious diseases, including gastroenteritis from polluted water, skin infections, and hepatitis A[26].

In the West Bank, military operations have caused significant damage to civilian infrastructure, including the forced demolition of over 2,000 Palestinian homes and extensive damage to public infrastructure such as roads[31]. This widespread destruction, coupled with increased violence, movement restrictions, and economic disruption, severely impacts daily life and contributes to extreme mental distress and heightened mental health concerns among the population[31][32]. sdg-1.summary:
Internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Gaza are enduring severe hardships due to the ongoing conflict and its devastating impact on infrastructure and essential services. The conditions in IDP sites are dire, characterized by worn-out tents, a lack of mattresses, and insufficient food, water, and sanitation facilities, which are exacerbated by the approaching adverse weather conditions [1][2][12]. The shortage of basic necessities has led to a continued spread of skin diseases and an acute lack of medications, further affecting the health of the displaced population [6][11]. Women and girls are particularly vulnerable due to the limited availability of menstrual hygiene management (MHM) kits and dignity kits, with over 800,000 kits needed compared to the 1,900 distributed [2][10][12][13]. This shortage increases their risk of disease and gender-based violence (GBV) [2][12][13].

The conflict has also severely impacted food security, with exorbitantly high food prices and a major shortage of food and water [12][21][24]. Vegetables are ten times more expensive than before the war, and a kilo of tomatoes costs nearly 8-10 [14][24]. The scarcity of food and clean water has led to outbreaks of diarrhea and skin diseases [51]. Cash shortages further hinder the use of Cash and Voucher Assistance (CVA), negatively affecting living conditions and increasing the risk of violence or exploitation for women and girls [5][17][18][26].

Israeli airstrikes have compounded these challenges by targeting shelters, including schools and mosques, resulting in numerous fatalities and injuries among displaced civilians [41][42][43][44][47]. The strikes have damaged over 370,000 housing units, completely destroying 79,000 homes, and severely affected 68% of cropland and roads [52]. This destruction has led to overcrowding and appalling sanitary conditions, with only 17 of 36 hospitals remaining partially functional due to a lack of fuel, medical supplies, and clean water [52][112].

Efforts to address these challenges include UNRWA's protection teams identifying and responding to protection risks, and partners distributing dignity kits and providing psychosocial support [11][15][16]. However, the need far exceeds the available resources, and humanitarian aid movement remains dangerous, with aid convoys often blocked or shot at [123][129]. The World Food Programme (WFP) has ceased food basket distributions due to restricted flow of essential goods [31].

The conflict has also had a profound impact on individuals like Taleen Al-Hinnawi and Nada Al-Gharib, who have lost family members and face the challenge of adjusting to life in orphanage camps [61][62][63]. Despite the hardships, they find a sense of community and resilience among fellow displaced persons [61][68].

The Israeli military's Operation Iron Swords has included a complete blockade of the Gaza Strip, leading to a death toll exceeding 41,800 and thousands missing under rubble [71][72][76]. The blockade has resulted in severe food insecurity, with 745,000 people facing emergency levels and 495,000 facing catastrophic levels of food insecurity [121][130]. Israel's actions, including the destruction of agricultural lands and blocking of food and medicine deliveries, have contributed to famine conditions [132][134].

Humanitarian organizations are working to mitigate these challenges by providing hot meals, clean water, and nutritional supplements to displaced families [81][82][86]. Oxfam and UNICEF are advocating for a ceasefire, humanitarian access, and accountability for the destruction and deprivation faced by Gaza's population [116][125]. Despite these efforts, the situation remains critical, with the destruction of infrastructure and essential services continuing to impact daily life and exacerbate the suffering of Gaza's residents [91][92][93][98].

Internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Gaza are enduring severe hardships due to a combination of inadequate shelter, food, and sanitation, exacerbated by ongoing conflict and adverse weather conditions. The sites visited by UNRWA protection monitors reveal dire conditions characterized by worn-out tents and tarpaulins, a lack of mattresses, key non-food items (NFIs), and insufficient food, water, and sanitation[1][2][12]. The shortage of tents not only limits the expansion of group-based psychosocial support but also hinders the provision of safe spaces or temporary accommodation for unaccompanied children[1][2][12][13]. The capacity to conduct repairs or provide alternative housing is severely limited, leaving families in damaged buildings with little more than awareness-raising support[12].

The scarcity of basic necessities has led to a continued spread of skin diseases and an acute lack of medications[6][11]. Women and girls are particularly vulnerable due to the limited availability of menstrual hygiene management (MHM) and dignity kits, which increases their risk of disease and gender-based violence (GBV)[2][12][13]. An estimated need for over 800,000 dignity kits starkly contrasts with the mere 1,900 distributed by partners[10][15]. Cash shortages further exacerbate living conditions, increasing the risk of violence or exploitation for women and girls and undermining the ability of partners to pay local service providers and staff salaries[5][17][18].

The conflict has severely impacted the availability of essential services and resources. Israeli air strikes have damaged over 370,000 housing units, completely destroying 79,000 homes, and severely affected 68% of cropland and roads[32]. This destruction has led to overcrowding and appalling sanitary conditions, with food scarcity and a lack of clean water causing outbreaks of diarrhoea and skin diseases[31][37]. The blockade of the Gaza Strip as part of Operation Iron Swords has resulted in a death toll exceeding 41,800, with thousands more missing under the rubble of destroyed buildings[41][42][46]. The strikes have targeted shelters, including mosques and schools, killing those seeking refuge there[41].

Efforts to address these challenges include UNRWA's protection teams identifying and responding to protection risks in areas like Khan Younis and Deir al Balah[15]. Protection Monitors conduct awareness sessions, focus group discussions, and key informant interviews, while monitoring aid distribution and following up on vulnerable cases[11]. The Site Management Working Group (SMWG) partners have monitored 38 sites hosting approximately 170,875 people[11]. Child Protection partners are planning winterization activities, including procuring psychosocial support kits and winter clothes[16]. Despite these efforts, the distribution of dignity kits remains far below the estimated need, and the GBV sub-cluster is assessing the potential for cash assistance to address urgent needs[14][15].

The primary drivers of disease in Gaza are the poor water, sanitation, and hygiene conditions, worsened by overcrowding in shelters[26]. The breakdown of sanitation infrastructure has led to a proliferation of disease vectors, and the collapse of waste management systems contributes to contamination[22][25]. The lack of clean water and hygiene products is causing outbreaks of diarrhoea and skin diseases, with the risk of epidemics skyrocketing due to the inability to maintain minimal hygiene standards[21][25][27].

Measures to provide food and water to displaced people include distributing hot meals, food packs, vegetables, and vouchers, along with clean water and nutritional supplements[51]. Over 40 million hot meals have been distributed, and water is provided to 110,000 people daily[51][52]. Nutritional supplements are supplied to 35,000 pregnant women and young children every two weeks, and a Community-based Management of Acute Malnutrition program has been launched[52][56].

The destruction of agricultural land and infrastructure has severely limited access to food, with ongoing bombardments and fuel shortages forcing bakeries to shut down[73][74]. The contamination of soil and water resources may persist for years, hampering access to safe drinking water[74]. The UN and humanitarian partners have developed a Winterization Plan to address critical needs, but interventions are hindered by the lack of unimpeded entry of humanitarian items, fuel availability, and safe humanitarian movement[75][79]. The approaching rainy season is expected to further deteriorate living conditions, putting hundreds of thousands at heightened risk of health hazards and limited access to essential services[77].

Internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Gaza are enduring severe hardships, living in conditions marked by worn-out tents, a lack of mattresses, and insufficient food, water, and sanitation, as observed by UNRWA protection monitors[1][2]. The approaching adverse weather conditions exacerbate these challenges[2]. The scarcity of basic necessities has led to the spread of skin diseases and an acute lack of medications[6]. IDPs express deep distress over the inadequate assistance they receive[2]. Women and girls are particularly vulnerable due to the limited availability of sanitary pads, dignity, and menstrual hygiene management (MHM) kits, with over 800,000 dignity kits needed compared to the 1,900 distributed by partners[2][10]. The shortage of blankets, shoes, warm clothes, and other winter items is expected to worsen their suffering[9]. Additionally, the lack of tents hinders the expansion of group-based psychosocial support and the provision of safe spaces or temporary accommodation for unaccompanied children[1][2]. Cash shortages further deteriorate living conditions and increase the risk of violence or exploitation for women and girls[5].

The situation is compounded by Israeli airstrikes, which have recently targeted at least six UN-run schools sheltering displaced Palestinians, resulting in tens of fatalities, including children and women[11][14][17]. In particular, airstrikes on a mosque and the Ibn Rushd School in Al-Zawaida killed at least 24 Palestinians, including children, and injured 93 others[12][13]. These attacks force families to move from one area to another, only to be bombed in the schools and tents where they seek refuge[15]. The constant Israeli attacks have damaged over 370,000 housing units, completely destroying 79,000 homes, and severely affected 68% of cropland and roads[22]. This has led to overcrowding and appalling sanitary conditions, with food scarcity and a lack of clean water and hygiene products causing outbreaks of diarrhoea and skin diseases[21]. As of September 2024, only 17 of 36 hospitals remain partially functional, suffering from a lack of fuel, medical supplies, and clean water due to ongoing attacks[22].

The Israeli military's Operation Iron Swords has imposed a complete blockade on the Gaza Strip, resulting in a death toll exceeding 41,800 since October 7, according to the enclave's health ministry[41]. Thousands are reported missing under the rubble of destroyed buildings[46]. Heavy strikes have been reported across northern Gaza, with dozens of explosions from air strikes and tank shelling[43][46]. The Israeli army has issued evacuation orders, leading residents to flee without knowing where to go or having means of transportation[41]. Strikes have targeted shelters, including a mosque and a school, killing those seeking refuge there[41]. Hunger is spreading due to the lack of basic supplies, and residents are ordered to move to the humanitarian zone in southern Gaza, though some are unwilling due to perceived dangers and reports of the army shooting at people there[41][48].

The destruction of homes and infrastructure has profoundly impacted the daily lives of Gaza residents. An Islamic Relief staff member reported that their house is damaged and uninhabitable, and their colleagues have lost their homes[51]. The staff member also noted that their office, along with children's schools, a mosque, a hospital, restaurants, and a church, has been destroyed, systematically dismantling their lives[51]. Civilian infrastructure, including schools, religious buildings, hospitals, and bakeries, has been destroyed[52]. The healthcare system has been systematically dismantled, with most primary healthcare centers out of action and critical services like oncology and specialized pediatric surgery unavailable[53][54]. There is no electricity in Gaza, except for generators hindered by the high price of fuel, leading to a significant drop in access to services such as water, food, and education[58]. Infectious diseases like gastroenteritis, skin infections, and hepatitis A are on the rise due to polluted water[56].

In the West Bank, military operations have caused significant damage to civilian infrastructure, including the forced demolition of over 2,000 Palestinian homes and massive damage to public infrastructure, such as roads[61]. This has led to widespread destruction and severe impacts on daily life, contributing to extreme mental distress and increased mental health concerns among the population[61][62]. These operations have also resulted in forced displacement[62].
